result.markdown:
--- title: "QML -- Week 5" subtitle: "Varying effects I" --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Introduction ::: callout-warning #### Create a Quarto RStudio project for this course Create an RStudio project for the course and within that add the usual folders `data/` and `code/` (do not include the forward slash `/` in the name! It is just there to mark that those are folders.) When working through these tutorials, **make sure you are in the course Quarto/RStudio Project** you created. You know you are in a Quarto Project because you can see the name of the Project in the top-right corner of RStudio, next to the light-blue cube icon. If you see `Project (none)` in the top-right corner, that means **you are not** in a Quarto Project. To make sure you are in the Quarto project, you can open the project by going to the project folder in File Explorer (Win) or Finder (macOS) and double click on the `.Rproj` file. ::: In this tutorial, you have to run Bayesian regression models with data from Winter 2012 (DOI [10.1016/j.wocn.2012.08.006](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.wocn.2012.08.006)). You can get the data [here](/data/winter2012/polite.csv) (right-click and download). This page explains the meaning of the columns in the data: . ## Mean f0 Fit a regression model to answer the following question: > Do the months spent in Germany modulate the effect of attitude on mean f0? The model should have the following variables: - `f0mn` as the outcome variable. - `gender`, `months_ger` and `attitude` as predictors. Use indexing (`0 +`). - Add varying effects as needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} polite <- read_csv("data/winter2012/polite.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 224 Columns: 27 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (6): subject, gender, birthplace, musicstudent, task, attitude dbl (21): months_ger, scenario, total_duration, articulation_rate, f0mn, f0s... ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: We fit a Bayesian regression model with mean f0 as the outcome variable, using a Gaussian family. As predictors, we include gender, attitude and months spent in germany. We also model an interaction between gender and attitude and between gender, attitude and months in germany. We also let the effect of attitude to vary by subject. (The effects of gender and months in Germany cannot vary by subject because they are within-subject variables). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} f0_bm <- brm( f0mn ~ 0 + gender:attitude + gender:attitude:months_ger + (0 + attitude | subject), data = polite, cores = 4, seed = my_seed, file = "data/cache/f0_bm" ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(f0_bm) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Family: gaussian Links: mu = identity; sigma = identity Formula: f0mn ~ 0 + gender:attitude + gender:attitude:months_ger + (0 + attitude | subject) Data: polite (Number of observations: 212) Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1; total post-warmup draws = 4000 Multilevel Hyperparameters: ~subject (Number of levels: 16) Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS sd(attitudeinf) 24.39 6.81 13.54 40.72 1.00 1848 sd(attitudepol) 26.95 7.21 16.01 43.94 1.00 1682 cor(attitudeinf,attitudepol) 0.91 0.10 0.64 1.00 1.00 2345 Tail_ESS sd(attitudeinf) 2082 sd(attitudepol) 1855 cor(attitudeinf,attitudepol) 2857 Regression Coefficients: Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat genderF:attitudeinf 263.88 11.61 240.67 286.67 1.00 genderM:attitudeinf 123.26 16.35 89.37 154.81 1.00 genderF:attitudepol 242.11 12.63 217.01 267.78 1.00 genderM:attitudepol 113.50 17.47 79.51 147.79 1.00 genderF:attitudeinf:months_ger -0.16 0.12 -0.40 0.10 1.00 genderM:attitudeinf:months_ger 0.75 0.69 -0.62 2.14 1.00 genderF:attitudepol:months_ger -0.06 0.13 -0.33 0.20 1.00 genderM:attitudepol:months_ger 0.69 0.74 -0.79 2.20 1.00 Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS genderF:attitudeinf 1393 1472 genderM:attitudeinf 1265 1865 genderF:attitudepol 1506 1626 genderM:attitudepol 1419 2144 genderF:attitudeinf:months_ger 1944 1915 genderM:attitudeinf:months_ger 1528 1926 genderF:attitudepol:months_ger 1868 1781 genderM:attitudepol:months_ger 1644 1991 Further Distributional Parameters: Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS sigma 31.76 1.67 28.71 35.23 1.00 5114 2692 Draws were sampled using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1). ``` ::: ::: The 95% CrI of the effect of months in Germany on mean f0 when the attitude is polite and gender is female is \[-0.4, +0.1\], while it is \[-0.33, +0.2\] when the attitude is informal. The CrIs for gender male are much more uncertain. Given the level of uncertainty of the effect of months spent in Germany it is not wise to make any inference in relation to the research question and further comparisons will not be attempted. See @fig-f0 for the expected mean f0 based on the model. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot( conditional_effects(f0_bm, "months_ger:attitude", conditions = make_conditions(polite, "gender")), points = TRUE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Expected mean f0.](tutorial-w05-solution_files/figure-html/fig-f0-bm-1.png){#fig-f0-bm width=672} ::: ::: ## H1-H2 difference If you have time, run another regression model to answer the following research question: > Does being a music student modulate the effect of attitude on the H1-H2 difference? The H1-H2 difference is correlated with breathiness: the higher the difference, the more breathy the voice quality. We fit a Bayesian regression with H1-H2 difference as the outcome variable, with a Gaussian family. As predictors, the model has attitude, gender and whether the participant is a music student. We let the affect of attitude to vary by participant. @fig-h1h2-bm shows the expected H1-H2 difference depending on attitude, gender and music student based on the model. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} h1h2_bm <- brm( H1H2 ~ 0 + attitude:musicstudent:gender + (0 + attitude | subject), data = polite, cores = 4, seed = my_seed, file = "data/cache/h1h2_bm" ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(h1h2_bm) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Family: gaussian Links: mu = identity; sigma = identity Formula: H1H2 ~ 0 + attitude:musicstudent:gender + (0 + attitude | subject) Data: polite (Number of observations: 224) Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1; total post-warmup draws = 4000 Multilevel Hyperparameters: ~subject (Number of levels: 16) Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS sd(attitudeinf) 1.97 0.44 1.28 2.94 1.00 1529 sd(attitudepol) 2.04 0.44 1.35 3.09 1.00 1631 cor(attitudeinf,attitudepol) 0.92 0.09 0.67 1.00 1.00 1705 Tail_ESS sd(attitudeinf) 2159 sd(attitudepol) 2358 cor(attitudeinf,attitudepol) 2351 Regression Coefficients: Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderF 3.44 0.84 1.76 5.07 1.00 attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderF 3.15 0.88 1.34 4.81 1.00 attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderF 2.28 1.22 -0.09 4.69 1.00 attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderF 0.89 1.25 -1.60 3.38 1.00 attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderM 6.47 1.07 4.32 8.51 1.00 attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderM 6.65 1.12 4.41 8.81 1.00 attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderM 5.89 1.20 3.46 8.23 1.00 attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderM 6.42 1.25 3.94 8.91 1.00 Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderF 1313 2036 attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderF 1399 2221 attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderF 2075 2476 attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderF 2108 2346 attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderM 1533 2327 attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderM 1665 2202 attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderM 1673 2173 attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderM 1737 2308 Further Distributional Parameters: Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS sigma 1.61 0.08 1.46 1.77 1.00 6745 2961 Draws were sampled using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1). ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} conditional_effects(h1h2_bm, "musicstudent:attitude", conditions = make_conditions(polite, "gender")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Expected H1-H2 difference](tutorial-w05-solution_files/figure-html/fig-h1h2-bm-1.png){#fig-h1h2-bm width=672} ::: ::: To answer the RQ of whether the difference between informal and polite attitude is affected by whether the participant is a music student, we calculate the following estimands: - Difference between H1-H2 in informal vs polite in female participants, separately for music students (`mus_f`) vs non-music students (`nomus_f`). - Difference between H1-H2 in informal vs polite in male participants, separately for music students (`mus_m`) vs non-music students (`nomus_m`). - Difference between the differences for female and male participants (`no_mus_f` and `no_mus_m`). This estimand is the one we need to answer the RQ. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} h1h2_draws <- as_draws_df(h1h2_bm, "^b_", regex = TRUE) h1h2_draws <- h1h2_draws |> mutate( nomus_f = `b_attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderF` - `b_attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderF`, mus_f = `b_attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderF` - `b_attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderF`, no_mus_f = mus_f - nomus_f, nomus_m = `b_attitudepol:musicstudentno:genderM` - `b_attitudeinf:musicstudentno:genderM`, mus_m = `b_attitudepol:musicstudentyes:genderM` - `b_attitudeinf:musicstudentyes:genderM`, no_mus_m = mus_m - nomus_m, ) # Pivot for plotting h1h2_music_diff <- h1h2_draws |> select(no_mus_f, no_mus_m) |> pivot_longer(everything()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Dropping 'draws_df' class as required metadata was removed. ``` ::: ::: @fig-h1h2-music-diff shows the estimated difference between the by-attitude H1-H2 difference in music vs non-music students, separately for female and male students. There is some indication of a difference for female participants, but not so much for male participants. Let's calculate 95, 80, and 60% CrI. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} h1h2_music_diff |> ggplot(aes(value, fill = name)) + geom_vline(xintercept = 0) + geom_density(alpha = 0.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Music-student difference of attitude difference in H1-H2 in female and male participants.](tutorial-w05-solution_files/figure-html/fig-h1h2-music-diff-1.png){#fig-h1h2-music-diff width=672} ::: ::: The 80% CrI [-2.16, -0.04] for femal participants suggests a difference based on whether the participant is a music student or not, at 80% confidence, although the magnitude of the difference is quite uncertain and if a difference is indeed present it is 2 db or smaller. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} h1h2_music_diff |> group_by(name) |> summarise( ci = list(round(quantile2(value, probs = c(0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.8, 0.9, 0.95)), 2)) ) |> unnest_wider(ci) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: In sum, the results are inconclusive as to which being a music student makes a difference in H1-H2 differences between polite and informal speech, particularly for male speakers. For female speakers, there might be a slightly greater difference in the H1-H2 difference of polite vs informal speech when they are music students relative to non-music students, but the effect could be anything between 2 and almost 0 db. ## Reporting You should mention the varying effects you included when reporting the model specification. For example, for the following model: ``` r ota_bm_2 <- brm( Words.RT ~ 0 + Condition:Contrast + (0 + Condition:Contrast | Subject) + (0 + Condition:Contrast | Version), family = lognormal, data = ota2009, seed = my_seed, cores = 4, file = "data/cache/ota_bm_2" ) ``` > As varying (aka random) effects, we included by-participant and by-list varying terms for the interaction between condition and contrast.
